title: Merlin shares tumble on profit warning
text:
Merlin shares tumble on profit warning John Aglionby ©Alamy The Smiler rollercoaster theme park ride at Alton Towers 
Shares in Merlin Entertainment fell 8 per cent on Monday after the attractions operator warned that its profit would be hit by last month’s rollercoaster crash at its Alton Towers theme park. 
Merlin, which shut Alton Towers for five days after the crash and closed several rides at other parks, said earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation for the theme park business this year would be around £40m-£50m, compared to £87m in 2014. More Ladbrokes and Coral confirm merger 
It previously forecast mid-single digit growth in ebitda this year. The financial impact of the accident, which left four people seriously injured, may last into 2016, it added. 
Nick Varney, Merlin chief executive, said the June 2 accident on the Smiler ride, not only “stopped the momentum” at the theme parks as they were entering their peak period but the expected pick-up in attendance in the past few weeks had not materialised. 
“Just as we could have been going at full throttle, we had to stop the engines and that took all the momentum out of the market,” he said. Some marketing and promotion has since resumed but it has not had the desired effect on revenues. 
“We were expecting it to move the needle and it hasn’t,” said Mr Varney. 
He declined to say by how much visitor numbers had fallen and said it was not clear how long it would take for “residual concerns to work their way through the system”, suggesting the impact would linger into 2016. “In 12 to 18 months’ time I believe Alton Towers will be back where it was,” he said. 
The cost base would not be cut, he said, because that would be hard to reverse if visitor numbers did recover. 
Analysts at Shore Capital said the downgrade was larger than expected. “However, we are encouraged by the better trading elsewhere and while not trying to trivialise the tragic events, historically theme parks around the globe have recovered relatively quickly from such events,” they wrote in a note. “At this stage we think this [accident] remains a one off event that should be treated as such.” 
Merlin’s share price fell 8 per cent to 390p in early trading, its biggest one-day fall according to Reuters, before recovering to 403p. 
Revenues have also been hit by the weakening euro deterring visitors to London, particularly at Merlin’s Madame Tussauds waxworks museum. 
“We expect there will be a lot less British holidaymakers in London and a lot less French, German, Italian and Spanish holidaymakers in London,” Mr Varney said. 
Visitor numbers at Thorpe Park, where rides were also closed after the Smiler accident, have picked up faster than at Alton Towers. 
Revenues at Legoland, another major Merlin-run theme park, have been strong, Mr Varney said. 
At the group level, Merlin said the impact of the losses at the theme parks would be partially offset by better than expected financing costs, central cost savings and improved trading elsewhere in the group. Underlying profit before tax this year is expected to be broadly in line with last year’s £249m. 
Mr Varney said he had not come under shareholder pressure to step down. “We’ve had one tragic accident in the company’s history that shouldn’t have happened,” he said. “We’re putting that right but it doesn’t take away from the fact that this is a very strong business. It will just take a period of time to recover.”
